body.p:
Yours of the 26th Ulto
came duly to hand as well as the P
Books. Abrn? Moise desires a state
-ment of a/c & please send it to me, let
it be from the beginning, I think he
owes at least 3 years to April 1858, he
will not pay in advance & I have
to send after its due several times.
You complain of the ingratitude
of mankind, I thought you had suf
ferred so much & so often that you
had become used to their ingratitude
& had therefore become a philosopher
in that respect. Here I must make
you acquainted with the course of
the teacher whom I selected for our
Children & of whom you make
mention in your last as not having
ever written you. I dont know
whether it came to your knowledge
that he was a drunkard, for he
certainly could not all at once
or since his sojourn with us, have
become so, but no less certain it is
that he indulged in private, & managed

until 2d night ? to keep it from
the public eye, when on that night at
his boarding house he was so intox
-icated that he was compelled to leave
the table where the recital of the prayers
were going on ? was annoying
to those around him. He must there
-fore have obtained his liquor at a pub
-lic house & therefore partook of Homity?
His host & Hostess, not wishing to injure
him suffered this dereliction, to remain
within themselves under the promise
that he would leave their house, as
it was impossible to board him longer
& thus I as well as the people were
kept unacquainted with this vice
until after Mr. Jacobs resignation as Hazan
when I called upon him to read
the Law, presuming that he was a pro
=per person, & he did read on Sabbath
when those who were acquainted
murmured strongly & loudly when it
reached my ears, of course no blame
could be attached to me, as I then
was only made acquainted of his
weakness to call it by a gentle name
of course some action was requisite
& I did not allow him to read again

the school committee inquired first into
the matter as well as the school, & they
reported the result to the Board of
Trustees, who summoned Mr Cohen &
his accusers before them. Mr Cohen
would not appear unless he had in
writing the charges against him, we
accommodated him. He appeared & totally
denied the charge, his accusers ap
=peared & substantiated the charge by
others, in addition to which others not
belonging or connected with the congre
gation having seen him take at
one drink in a bar room nearly
a tumbler of brandy—with these facts
the board of trustees discharged him
but submitted their action to the con
gregation, when they confirmed our action
The board in their kindness of feeling
for him ordered a quarters salary to
be paid him, which would not be
due him until next August. The
gentleman turns away in disappointment
and sues the congregation for another
quarters salary which he thinks him
self entitled to because I engaged him
for a year. Now my dear Sir, we
ought to do good for our kind so that
we may be repaid in such a manner

I was in hopes he would have
been thankful for our consideration
in giving him what he did not deserve
but he has thought it wiser to seek
justice in a court of Law

I shall be obliged by your favour
-ing me with his precedents, & all
you know about him prior to his
coming here, why he was dismissed
from the congregations as well
as from the school which he super
=intended. It is necessary for the Vin
-dication of the cause of Virtue & jus
=tice we have Black sheep around
us & no one should be allowed
to wear a cloak who is unworthy
of it & if this man is a drunkard
why the better for us & all Israel that
the mark should be torn from
his face. We have been favored
with the presence of the Rev H. Jacobs
of Richmond who preached last Sabbath
& will do so on the next, his hearers
were much pleased with his mild
& gentlemanly manner & his discourse
was plain & sensible. He is no orator
our people are much pleased with his
manners & he is intelligent & no doubt a
good & con? Jew. As ever your friend
